moves.1. d4 e5: I decided that I would experiment with the Englund Gambit, but my opponent did not play along.
moves.2. d5 d6 3. e4 Nf6 4. Nc3 Be7 5. Nf3 O-O: I think this move might have been a mistake.  It loses a tempo by moving a piece twice in the opening, and it's not a great square for the N.
moves.7... c6 8. c4 cxd5 9. cxd5 Nc5 10. O-O: I think Qc2 would have saved the e4 pawn.
moves.10... Nfxe4 11. Bxe4 Nxe4 12. Nc3: Black has sneaked a pawn.  White loses another tempo by offering the exchange of the N, which has moved yet again.  Even better for Black, the exchange will leave a backward pawn on an open file.
This creates a complicated series of exchanges that allows Black to get the upper hand.  Yet defending stoically might not have been much fun either.
moves.16... Bxf3 17. Bxe7 e4: This strange-looking move gains a tempo with the attack on the Q.
moves.18. Rxe4 Bxe4 19. Qxe4 Qxc3: Black sneaks another pawn and also has the benefit of winning the exchange.
moves.20. Rf1: This seems passive.  Perhaps Re1 was an improvement?
moves.20... Rfe8 21. Qh4 Rc4 22. Qg5 f6: This tactical trick wins more material.
moves.23. Qe3 Qxe3 24. fxe3 Rxe7: Now Black, with a R and a pawn to the good, should win the endgame easily.
moves.25. Re1 Re5: White resigned here.  Black can keep taking pawns, while moving the K to f7 to keep White's R from penetrating on the e file.  White will be tied down to a hopeless defense of the K.
